Well, it's essential because there are parts of the telescope that wear out just like any other machine.
And the two crucial parts we worry about are the batteries, which supply power to keep the telescope warm, and the gyroscopes that allow us to point the telescope anywhere in the sky.
And the batteries are the same batteries that were installed at launch in 1990.
So they're now 16 years old, and just like the batteries in your PC or even your car battery, you know, they wear out after they've been recharged many times.

But the gyroscopes also wear out.
They spin.
They're the most precise gyroscopes ever made, and they typically have lifetimes of three or four years.

And that's because when the telescope - every 96 minutes it goes around the Earth, and about a third of that time it's in the shadow behind, you know, in the night side of the Earth.
And during that time, we need to put power to the telescope to keep it warm.
And if we don't do that, it will freeze up, the truss will warp in ways that we don't even want to contemplate.
And so we do that by charging the batteries through sunlight on the light side and the discharging the batteries and heating it on the dark side.
So if the batteries really fail to hold charge, the telescope will freeze up in a matter of just a few days.
And we worried about that a lot because they are the originals.
